content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to report detailed nursing expenditures, including wages and benefits for different levels of nursing staff. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures, including wages for various staff levels. The Secretary will redesign cost reports with input from private accountants. New quality measures will be developed for a payment system. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures, including wages for various staff levels. Quality measures for a payment system will be developed in consultation with experts and stakeholders, including process, structural, and outcome measures. The quality measures for a payment system in skilled nursing facilities must be precise, valid, reliable, and structured to minimize provider burden. It should include a measure for nursing home staffing levels and make provisions for small facilities. The Secretary will establish criteria for determining the size of nursing facilities to ensure meaningful data on quality performance measures. The new measures will be posted on the Medicare program website. Additionally, payments to skilled nursing facilities will be linked to their quality performance. The Secretary will develop methods to link payment rates to quality in skilled nursing facilities, ensuring rates are not lower than 2004 levels. The Secretary will develop methods to link payment rates to quality in skilled nursing facilities, in consultation with various stakeholders. These methods will tie a portion of a provider's payment to performance on quality indicators, with special payments for facilities that enhance quality. The Secretary may test methods for quality improvement in skilled nursing facilities through pilot studies, demonstration projects, and other appropriate methods, with a deadline for developing and testing quality measures and payment methods. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, including an examination of Medicare's cross-subsidization of care for Medicaid. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, including Medicare's cross-subsidization of care for Medicaid patients, industry margins, current trends impact on costs, demographic changes, and options for payment and financing of long-term care services over the next five decades. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit annual and final reports to Congress on the impact of Medicaid financing for nursing home care over the next five decades. The final report will include the results of a study on the amendments made and their effects. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for changes to the Medicare payment system for extended care services in skilled nursing facilities, as well as an analysis of alternative approaches to addressing identified issues.
